passages.text: Average building start price up, with a few exceptions

According to order receipt data for 50 major construction companies released on 29 August, building construction orders fell \(29\%\) y- y (down \(30\%\) in Japan) in July. Orders were down for factories, offices, and lodging facilities. We attribute this to a fallback from a concentration of multiple large orders for factory projects a year earlier and limited orders for redevelopment and other major projects booked in July 2025. We think orders for major redevelopment projects and factory projects may remain in a fallow period from July onwards, resulting in sustained y- y declines over multiple months. That said, general contractors have plentiful order backlogs, and inquiries about other projects, ie, inbound- related projects and data centers, look to have been solid, on which basis we envision sustained improvements in margins at the point of order thanks to a focus on margins. Civil engineering orders rose \(14\%\) in July (down \(3\%\) in Japan). In Japan, orders fell for roads, harbors, and airports. Road project orders from local governments and expressway companies declined. Expressway operators look to have been reining in new orders because of budget shortages, and we expect orders for expressway projects to continue to fall in August and beyond.

The construction start statistics for July, announced on the same day, showed building construction start floor space down \(13\%\) , with residential starts down \(9\%\) and nonresidential starts down \(21\%\) . Among nonresidential buildings, start floor area was down for offices, warehouses, and factories. There were few large- scale project starts again in July, and we think that SMEs continued to rein in capex because of rising construction costs. The average building start price (projected construction costs divided by building start floor area, 12- month moving average) of \(309,000 / \mathrm{m}^2\) was slightly up from \(301,000 / \mathrm{m}^2\) in June (Figure 1). Average building start price was broadly flat for residential projects and up for nonresidential projects. For nonresidential buildings, average prices were down for manufacturing and lodging, but up for other categories including services, education, and transportation, and the mix also contributed to an improvement in average prices for nonresidential buildings as a whole thanks to a decline in exposure to the transportation sector, where average prices are low. We attribute the decline in average building start prices for manufacturing facilities to a decline in starts of large projects such as semiconductor and EV battery plants, which carry high prices. General contractors look to have continued to hike prices at the point of order, and major general contractors look to have received inquiries about an increased number of projects, up to those that would start around 28/3. With the number of special orders on the rise, in which projects are received without competitive bidding, we expect companies to continue to raise prices to pass through increases in labor and other costs and improve margins at the point of order.

The July survey on supply and demand for construction labor, announced on 25 August, showed an average shortage of \(1.8\%\) for the six skilled construction worker categories, and given that labor supply- demand conditions tend to tighten through the summer, tightened from \(1.1\%\) in the June survey, it was not as tight as the \(2.3\%\) reading a year earlier (Figure 4). Shortages increased y- y for scaffolding workers but eased for form workers (building construction) and steel reinforcement workers (building construction). We attribute the easing in the shortage for structural work to the low number of redevelopment projects and smaller projects. We see limited risk of labor supply- demand conditions tightening, given that many of the redevelopment projects currently being
planned would be due for completion in 29/3 or later, and start floor area for redevelopment projects and smaller projects is expected to decline over the near term.

Among engineering categories, the shortage of electricians was \(1.2\%\) (flat m- m) and the shortage of plumbers increased by \(0.6\mathrm{ppt}\mathrm{m} - \mathrm{m}\) to \(1.2\%\) (the equivalent readings for July 2024 were \(1.2\%\) and \(0.6\%\) ). The shortage of plumbers increased m- m in Hokkaido, which we attribute to progress with major semiconductor- related projects as well as seasonality. We expect supply- demand for plumbers to slacken from 27/3 onwards as major semiconductor projects are expected to run their course in 26/3. Shortages of electricians have remained high in absolute terms, and we expect supply- demand conditions to remain tight as a result of an increase in work related to data centers and power transmission networks.
Fig. 1: Building start prices and Building Construction Cost Index
Source: Nomura, based on MLIT and Construction Research Institute data
Fig. 2: Building start prices over long term (April 1985-)
Source: Nomura, based on Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism data
Fig. 3: Supply-demand for skilled construction workers, by region
Source: Nomura, based on Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism data
Fig. 4: Average shortages in six categories of skilled construction workers
Source: Nomura, based on Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism data
Fig. 5: Shortages by skill for skilled construction workers
Note: 12-month moving average basis. Source: Nomura, based on Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transportation and Tourism survey on construction labor supply-demand
Fig. 6: Price breakdown by type of construction work
Note: 2015 average market prices indexed to 100. Source: Nomura, based on Construction Research Institute data
Fig. 7: Orders at 50 largest construction companies
Note: Estimates by Nomura.
Source: Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism data, Nomura estimates

A rating of 'Buy', indicates that the analyst expects the stock to outperform the Benchmark over the next 12 months. A rating of 'Neutral', indicates that the analyst expects the stock to perform in line with the Benchmark over the next 12 months. A rating of 'Reduce', indicates that

the analyst expects the stock to underperform the Benchmark over the next 12 months. A 'Bearish' stance, indicates that the analyst expects the sector to underperform the Benchmark during the next 12 months. A Target Price, if discussed, indicates the analyst's forecast for the share price with a 12- month time horizon, reflecting in part the analyst's estimates for the company's earnings. The achievement of any target price may be impeded by general market and macroeconomic trends, and by other risks related to the company or the market, and may not occur if the company's earnings differ from estimates.

Investment trusts invest mainly in securities such as Japanese and foreign equities and bonds, whose prices fluctuate. Investment trust unit prices fluctuate owing to price fluctuations in the underlying assets and to foreign exchange rate fluctuations. As such, investment trusts carry the risk of losses. Fees and risks vary by investment trust. Maximum applicable fees are subject to change; please thoroughly read the written materials provided, such as prospectuses or documents delivered before making a contract.

In interest rate swap transactions and USD/JPY basis swap transactions ("interest rate swap transactions, etc."), only the agreed transaction payments shall be made on the settlement dates. Some interest rate swap transactions, etc. may require pledging of margin collateral. In some of these cases, transaction payments may exceed the amount of collateral. There shall be no advance notification of required collateral value or collateral ratios as they vary depending on the transaction. Interest rate swap transactions, etc. carry the risk of losses owing to fluctuations in market prices in the interest rate, currency and other markets, as well as reference indices. Losses incurred as such may exceed the value of margin collateral, in which case margin calls may be triggered. In the event that both parties agree to enter a replacement (or termination) transaction, the interest rates received (paid) under the new arrangement may differ from those in the original arrangement, even if terms other than the interest rates are identical to those in the original transaction. Risks vary by transaction. Please thoroughly read the written materials provided, such as documents delivered before making a contract and disclosure statements.

In OTC transactions of credit default swaps (CDS), no sales commission will be charged. When entering into CDS transactions, the protection buyer will be required to pledge or entrust an agreed amount of margin collateral. In some of these cases, the transaction payments may exceed the amount of margin collateral. There shall be no advance notification of required collateral value or collateral ratios as they vary depending on the financial position of the protection buyer. CDS transactions carry the risk of losses owing to changes in the credit position of some or all of the referenced entities, and/or fluctuations of the interest rate market. The amount the protection buyer receives in the event that the CDS is triggered by a credit event may undercut the total amount of premiums that he/she has paid in the course of the transaction. Similarly, the amount the protection seller pays in the event of a credit event may exceed the total amount of premiums that he/she has received in the transaction. All other conditions being equal, the amount of premiums that the protection buyer pays and that received by the protection seller shall differ. In principle, CDS transactions will be limited to financial instruments business operators and qualified institutional investors.
